text: hey what's up everybody I'm Tommy and
today I'm gonna show you how I made this
vise mounted router table with built-in
dust collection whether it's your first
time here or even if you've been here
before
welcome to one-minute workbench so when
I started out building this router table
I actually intended on it just being a
temporary jig but during the building
process it's sort of evolved into this
fully featured router table I started
off by cutting a piece for the mounting
block and a piece for the main surface
of the router table I check to see that
the router would have plenty of room and
make sure that the vise would not
interfere with its operation then I
secured the two pieces together
everywhere I used screws I made sure to
drill pilot holes and countersinks
I chose a bit that was larger than my
largest router bit marked a hole in the
center of the table and then drilled it
out on the drill press I lowered the bit
into the hole to help me align the
router to the approximate Center with
the router in the approximate center I
marked the mounting thread locations
with a pencil
I picked a Forstner bit large enough to
accommodate the tool for the bolt heads
and then drilled the holes
I finished drilling the holes with a
5/16 inch bit to match the size of the
mounting bolts I realized though that
the mounting holes on the router were
not symmetric so I had to do it again
starting from the bottom of the table
[Music]
[Music]
I mounted the router in place set the
bit depth for a round over and gave it a
preliminary test
[Music]
it was all looking good so I decided to
make a fence
[Music]
at first I just clamped the fence in
place to test it since that was working
well I figured I might as well continue
and make it adjustable I just copied the
cutout from the fence to the fence base
now I'm doing these cuts with a bandsaw
but you could easily do these with a
jigsaw or a coping saw
[Music]
with the fence built I started working
on the adjustment knobs
I rounded all of the corners using my
homemade disc sander
[Music]
since I had the sander out I took the
opportunity to go ahead and round over
all the other sharp corners I glued up
the knobs and then set those aside to
dry while the knobs were drying I took
some measurements and determined where I
wanted the mounting bolts for the
adjustable fence
I added mounting bolts but I'm not going
to go into detail on this because as
you'll see in just a bit I ended up
changing this feature I needed to add
slots so I scored a line and then
drilled a half-inch hole in the center
of that line with a half-inch bit
installed in the router I use the hole
to install a temporary fence for cutting
the slots
[Music]
[Music]
right when I finish making the knobs I
realized I wanted to change things so
that the bolts were part of the knobs
and not part of the table so I remove
the bolts and drilled out large counter
bores in the mounting block this allowed
me to use tea nuts in the mounting block
[Music]
[Music]
to make the new knobs I drilled a half
inch counter bore and a 5/16 inch
through hole in the main component and
then drilled a 5/8 inch hole in a
smaller bottomed component this will
make sense in just a little bit the hole
in the knob is intentionally left a
little bit smaller than the points of
the hex bolt this lets you hammer the
bolt in place and lets the wood form a
nice snug fit
to make sure the bolt didn't back out I
used a nylon locknut
I of course rounded all the corners and
then added the bottom components to the
knobs
[Music]
I scored a center line on a small scrap
and then transferred the center line all
the way around the ends
[Music]
then I used a pencil just to darken the
center line
[Music]
I very carefully drilled a half-inch
hole in the center of that line
I mounted the router in place inserted
the bit into the piece and squared the
piece with the outside edge of the table
then I made marks to match the
centerline I carefully transfer the
centerline to the table itself
this gave me a mark that is aligned with
the centre of the bit to test out the
mark I used a very accurate ruler to set
the depth of the fence to three inches
I made a test cut and then measured it
with a half inch bit the measurement to
the inside edge should be 2.75 inches it
looked really close so I measured it
with a caliper as you can see here it's
within two thousandths of an inch which
is really close with the success of the
first few cuts I decided to build the
rulers right into the table these steel
rulers were just a dollar each at Harbor
Freight I took some basic measurements
and cut them down to size using a pair
of tin snips then I use the rulers
themselves as a guide for drawing the
marks I would need to embed them in the
table
[Music]
I carefully aligned a scrap of wood and
clamped it in place so it could work as
a guide for my router
[Music]
I set the routers bit so that it would
cut a slot just a little bit deeper than
the thickness of the ruler
[Music]
[Music]
I then repeated the process for the
other side
[Music]
I added hot glue to the slot and set the
ruler in place unfortunately I was
moving kind of slow here and the glue
actually set up before I could get the
ruler pressed all the way down so I used
a heat gun to soften the glue so I could
push the ruler down until it was flush
with the table I thought it would be
quicker on the second one but I wasn't
and wound up having to use the heat gun
again the heat gun did the trick and the
rulers were perfectly flush with the
tabletop I removed the excess glue from
the rulers with a little bit of Windex
[Music]
I added the router back in place and use
the alignment block to make sure the
router was perfectly centered with the
line
my first test cut was at 2 inches and
with a 1/2 inch bit when measured to the
first edge should be 1.75 inches and as
you can see here the result was within 5
thousandths of an inch which is very
good with the accuracy on point I turned
my attention to creating dust collection
dust collection around the router itself
is the trickiest part so I started with
that for this first cut I was able to
trace the outline of the router and cut
it out on the bandsaw with a little bit
of back-and-forth I was able to get a
nice fit I then worked on the upright
walls of the box which I just had to
eyeball and make some test cuts on again
with a little bit of back-and-forth it
was done in just a few minutes the rest
of the box was just small square pieces
so I cut those out and started
assembling it
[Music]
I traced out the top of the box and
trimmed it to match the rest of the
pieces
[Music]
I changed my mind about the side I
wanted the vacuum on so I plugged the
original vacuum hole I cut a few small
blocks that would allow a threaded knob
to hold the Box in place
I then added a t-nut that would accept
the threaded knob
[Music]
I mark the threaded rod with a sharpie
so I could see where to trim it and then
trimmed it with a hacksaw and for safety
I filed the sharp edges until they were
smooth
I added some foam to the edges of the
box where it contoured to the shape of
the router I then added a small wooden
block and used some hot glue to attach a
foam block that would cover the last
remaining opening
these small guide blocks will just make
it easier to properly align the box the
bottom dust collection box allows the
router to be lowered and raised while
the box is in place with the bottom dust
collection box and the vacuum line in
place
I made a test cut it didn't collect all
the dust but I would say it got about
75% the threaded knob allows me to
quickly remove and replace the box when
I need to change router bits the top
dust collection box was a lot easier
than the bottom one I just glued it
clamped it in place and let it dry for
about an hour this top dust collection
box is perfect for round overs and
pretty much collects a hundred percent
of the dust
[Music]
with everything working good I took it
all apart and prepped it for finishing
for finishing
I applied six coats of satin water-based
polyurethane and sanded in between coats
[Music]
I'm really happy with how the router
table turned out as I mentioned before
it was just gonna be a temporary jig but
I'm happy that I took the time to go
ahead and build some more features into
